page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 56: Line 56:
Shortly after [[Jumu'ah]] (Friday prayers), tens of thousands of Egyptians assembled to protest; within hours the number rose to hundreds of thousands. ElBaradei arrived from [[Giza]], where he had been leading protests, to Cairo,<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d0H|archivedate=29 January 2011|title=ElBaradei To Join Egypt Protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[News24]]}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's No Going Back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|first=Jack|last=Shenker}}</ref> where he was placed under house arrest at a rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html|title=Report: ElBaradei Arrested in Egypt|work=[[Ynetnews]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/| title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak Expected To Speak; Curfew Imposed in Major Cities| accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> although he told [[Al Jazeera]] that he was unaware of his house arrest.<ref name="ajprotestersback">{{Cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html| title=Protesters Back on Egypt Streets| accessdate=29 January 2011| date=29 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref>
Shortly after [[Jumu'ah]] (Friday prayers), tens of thousands of Egyptians assembled to protest; within hours the number rose to hundreds of thousands. ElBaradei arrived from [[Giza]], where he had been leading protests, to Cairo,<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d0H|archivedate=29 January 2011|title=ElBaradei To Join Egypt Protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[News24]]}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's No Going Back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|first=Jack|last=Shenker}}</ref> where he was placed under house arrest at a rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html|title=Report: ElBaradei Arrested in Egypt|work=[[Ynetnews]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/| title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak Expected To Speak; Curfew Imposed in Major Cities| accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> although he told [[Al Jazeera]] that he was unaware of his house arrest.<ref name="ajprotestersback">{{Cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html| title=Protesters Back on Egypt Streets| accessdate=29 January 2011| date=29 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref>
â
Throughout the day, police fired [[tear gas]], [[rubber bullets]], and [[water cannon]]s into crowds during violent clashes between authorities and protesters throughout Egypt.<ref name="cnn-crackdown">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html|title=Egypt Cracks Down on Mass Protests|work=[[CNN]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Protestors in Suez took control of a police station, freed arrested protesters and then [[torched up|torched]] a nearby smaller local police post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]}}</ref><ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/28/friday-protests-liveblog|title=Live Blog â Egypt's Protests Erupt|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Port Said]] tens of thousands gathered and multiple government buildings were set ablaze.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net" /> In Suez, police shot and killed at least one protestor.<ref name="globemail" /> The government issued a 18:00 to 7:00 curfew, but protesters ignored it and were met by police.<ref name="globemail">{{Cite news| url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-protests-demand-mubaraks-ouster-army-imposes-curfew/article1886184/| title=Egypt Protests Demand Mubarak's Ouster; Army Imposes Curfew| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[The Globe and Mail]]| location=Toronto| first=Patrick| last=Martin}}</ref> In the evening, one of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP) headquarters buildings in Cairo<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:23 UTC</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31028059540819968|title=NDP's Headquarters Up in Flames|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> was set on fire by an unidentified culprit. While protesters paused for evening prayers, police continued firing tear gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31032922240716801|title=Tear Gas Canisters Were Fired|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
+
Throughout the day, police fired [[tear gas]], [[rubber bullets]], and [[water cannon]]s into crowds during violent clashes between authorities and protesters throughout Egypt.<ref name="cnn-crackdown">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html|title=Egypt Cracks Down on Mass Protests|work=[[CNN]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Protestors in Suez took control of a police station, freed arrested protesters and then [[Arson|burned down]] a nearby smaller local police post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]}}</ref><ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/28/friday-protests-liveblog|title=Live Blog â Egypt's Protests Erupt|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Port Said]] tens of thousands gathered and multiple government buildings were set ablaze.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net" /> In Suez, police shot and killed at least one protestor.<ref name="globemail" /> The government issued a 18:00 to 7:00 curfew, but protesters ignored it and were met by police.<ref name="globemail">{{Cite news| url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-protests-demand-mubaraks-ouster-army-imposes-curfew/article1886184/| title=Egypt Protests Demand Mubarak's Ouster; Army Imposes Curfew| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[The Globe and Mail]]| location=Toronto| first=Patrick| last=Martin}}</ref> In the evening, one of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP) headquarters buildings in Cairo<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:23 UTC</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31028059540819968|title=NDP's Headquarters Up in Flames|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> was set on fire by an unidentified culprit. While protesters paused for evening prayers, police continued firing tear gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31032922240716801|title=Tear Gas Canisters Were Fired|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
The Egyptian government deployed military in [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], and [[Suez]] to assist the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/28/world/main7293753.shtml|title=Cairo Crowds Overpower Police; Army Deployed|work=[[CBS News]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011128151048463975.html|title='Army Out' in Egyptian Capital|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera reported that in Suez the military wanted to avoid an open armed confrontation with protesters.<ref name="asianews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Cairo:-anti-Mubarak-protests-continue,-at-least-50-dead-from-clashes-20637.html|title=Egypt Cairo: Anti-Mubarak Protests Continue, at Least 50 Dead from Clashes |publisher=Asianews.it|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The same was reported in Alexandria.
The Egyptian government deployed military in [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], and [[Suez]] to assist the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/28/world/main7293753.shtml|title=Cairo Crowds Overpower Police; Army Deployed|work=[[CBS News]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011128151048463975.html|title='Army Out' in Egyptian Capital|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera reported that in Suez the military wanted to avoid an open armed confrontation with protesters.<ref name="asianews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Cairo:-anti-Mubarak-protests-continue,-at-least-50-dead-from-clashes-20637.html|title=Egypt Cairo: Anti-Mubarak Protests Continue, at Least 50 Dead from Clashes |publisher=Asianews.it|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The same was reported in Alexandria.
